awd_titl_txt: The Minimal Model Program in Positive and Mixed Characteristics
awd_abstract_narration:
Algebraic geometry is an active and influential field of mathematics. Its goal is to understand algebraic varieties, which are geometric shapes described by algebraic equations. Not only are such objects essential in many fields of mathematics, but they also come up naturally in other disciplines such as engineering, computer science, or biology. The principal investigator's research centers around the ultimate goal of classifying all algebraic varieties. The PI plans to capitalize on recent breakthroughs in other fundamental fields of mathematics, namely number theory and commutative algebra, to significantly extend the scope of this classification.

The principal investigator intends to apply new techniques, related to F-regularity, +-regularity, and mixed characteristic perfections, in order to provide a better understanding of the geometry and commutative algebra of schemes in positive and mixed characteristics.  A second aspect of the project is to further the Minimal Model Program in positive and mixed characteristics by focusing on dimensions three and four.  The PI plans to apply these results to obtain insight into the liftability of singularities and projective varieties from positive characteristic to characteristic zero, as well as the existence of rational points on varieties over finite fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to advance the classification of algebraic varieties, which are geometric shapes described by algebraic equations. These shapes play an important role not only in mathematics but also in other fields of science. The PI made several key contributions to our understanding of these geometric shapes by building on recent developments in other branches of mathematics, namely commutative algebra and arithmetic geometry.

One of the project’s major results was the proof of the three-dimensional Minimal Model Program in mixed characteristic by extending the theory of global F-splittings. Moreover, the work of the PI and his collaborators led to new insights into the behavior of singularities in mixed characteristics. The PI and his collaborator also showed that the four-dimensional Minimal Model Program holds for semistable varieties in both positive and mixed characteristics. Additionally, the PI contributed to the study of liftability, particularly in the context of globally F-split surfaces. Finally, the PI and collaborators developed a framework for quasi-F-splittings in birational geometry through a series of research articles and provided applications to birational geometry and the Minimal Model Program.

The PI regularly participated in seminars and conferences, sharing the projects' findings with the wider mathematical community. The PI was also engaged in mathematics outreach for high school students. These efforts have broadened understanding of mathematics and its role in various disciplines.

 


Last Modified: 10/14/2024
Modified by: Jakub Witaszek
